newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: S&P affirms Australian Capital Territory ratings.
newsitem.headline: S&P affirms Australian Capital Territory ratings.

text.p: Standard & Poor's said it has affirmed the Australian Capital Territory's (ACT) AAA for long term and A1-plus short-term local currency ratings.

It also affirmed the AA long-term and A1-plus short term foreign currency ratings on the ACT government. The foreign currency ratings reflected the sovereign credit risks associated with the rating on the Commonwealth Government of Australia.
The local currency outlook is stable, S&P said.
The local currency ratings of the ACT government reflected its extremely low debt levels, solid economic base and sound budgetary performance, the rating agency said.
The supporting relationship between the Federal and State/Territorial Governments in Australia also underpinned the rating, as did Canberra's place as the national capital.

The ACT has the lowest debt burden of all Australian States and Territories as a result of the Commonwealth Government not transferring any state-type general government debt to the ACT on self-government, and successive ACT governments taking a low-debt approach to financing activities, S&P said.

"Although the ACT economy has been severely affected by the cuts to Commonwealth outlays since the election of the Federal Liberal-National Party Government in March 1996, the ACT continues to have a solid fundametal economic base," S&P added,
On the stable outlook, S&P said that while borrowing requirements would add to debt over the next year, the ACT had significant flexibility to deal with any future revenue or expenditure shocks.
The foreign currency outlook was positive, reflecting the outlook on the Commonwealth Government of Australia.
